Y7a7Dh4qE10gXpMRgEMuaw.text: Very delicious food and great atmosphere but way overpriced. For the price, all curries should come with naan and rice at the least.

HOCo-5OIQyw9fC4mutZTLA.text: If I could give 10 stars I would. Strong recommendation! Flavours are authentic. One of the better restaurants in the city in terms of taste and style. You can skip the dishoom chain but not this !

FVjtjOaC5vDBNOHahoBboA.text: Yum yum yummy.... Inexpensive and very delicious Indian restaurant just by the Opera. Perfect place for after a show. Service is nice. Drinks are great. The lamb (and I usually don't like it!) was exquisite. The same with the grilled chicken in a skewer.

EMMAFl1F11k1USxGResRZQ.text: Fun place and good indian food.The locale is filled with  ceiling hanging marionettes. Very picturesque.Place is packed.We ordered a sample of dishes:Chicken samosasAloo Tikki ChaatDahi BhallaDali PuriDehli Chicken TikkaMalai Chicken Tikka likedit!!!Chicken WrapCheese NaanSteamed rice. Could eat the whole bowl.Washed down with Mango Bellinis, Mango smoothies, Masala Cola, tea.

zHy_yCKjJySfrVGDHxvaoQ.text: I must admit this place was the best Indian food we had out of India. The food was delicious, it was spicy and that's surprising. Every ingredient was handled with care unlike other places where they put premade stuff together. The chicken was tender, curry leaves were the star of the dish. We ordered the falooda  plate for dessert and it  was out of the world. Great ambiance,  beautiful presentation, quick service and pleasant staff. All in all must place to dine in.

CbOWpZflkqo-BI7Iw--bjA.text: Masala zone in covent garden does real decent indian street food. We ordered the thali which came with mixture of curries and dips. I also ordered a noodle dish which was ok. The restaurant is decorated with puppets hanging from the ceiling which is meant to represent an Indian party. The ambiance is nice and worth a vist.

eOZc5c-9J0P2P_1yglDdaA.text: I love it here. I like the way they try to make the food balanced. I like the way it is a little different and more authentic than most curry houses. Most of all, I just really like the flavours and the pleasant atmosphere. A great value meal that is tasty and filling. Perfect!

BqNbdR2ZloENFxGYhXBNuA.text: Masala Zone is a fab place. The food is mega-cheap and the set thali meals are to die for; they are only about 12 quid, but you'll leave incredibly full. The staff are always friendly and efficient. The best bit is the food is actually really healthy, with lots of veggies, as well as meat. I'm not saying it's likerabbit food; you probably won't even notice you're eating healthy stuff. The thalis are really well presented to; nicely laid out on silver platters. Wash it down with a nice beer and you're done. They've also started doing 2for1 vouchers too; they are going around the web somewhere at the moment.

rv1fZpK691MwRlHdwtYGFA.text: Pretty average. Had a starter - some sort of rrally rough lamb meat for a fiver. Yuk. Like dog food. Everything else was ok and pricey.

zdn_LfxyCkToxXpQ5ut0kg.text: This place is more cheery than the Soho Masala Zone and the staff are friendlier. It's a great location just behind the Covent Garden opera house and a convenient place to eat dinner if you're going to see an opera. The decorations can be a bit excessive, but the overall feeling is quite welcoming. I'd recommend the chicken and mango curry: it sounds like a bizarre combination of sweet and sour, but there is so much spice in the dish that you can barely taste the mango. Maybe parents good give to children in an attempt to make them eat the fruit without realising it. I just wish I could they could produce a better selection of pickles for the poppadoms.

7j35Foa_QtYzC13zwQeuMg.text: Ok, I've already reviewed the one in Camden but it is a small chain and this is a separate restaurant! Shared a veg and a meat starter. The wheat things with chickpeas weren't as nice as i've had before - they've changed a bit and for some reason poured yoghurt and chutney over the food - not the best and certainly not authentic. Still tasty though. Had thali with lamb and black cardomom as the main with a selection of veg dishes. Yum! Had the Goats Do Roam wine and tap water to drink, very good. The toilets are exquisite and the service impeccible. And for £22 each including service, fantastic value for money.

cLW0b6VuN2ZGfnB7bnUVFQ.text: I eat here so much Im surprised the management havent asked me if I wanted to buy shares in the place. Id settle for a loyalty card. A definite twist to the usual curries one experiences - I dont think Gujerati food is as well known as other regions. The masala tea takes me back to Goa and the thalis are amazing value for money. always a warm welcome.

v6dw_QB0lVKNQF7wJmLrmA.text: i'm not a fan of indian food but it's a must try if you're in london right? i was pleasantly surprised by this place. the waitress said what makes them unique is that they serve foods as if you were in an indian home in the form of a thali. not sure if this is true or not but the thali is basically a combo plate. i got a butter chicken thali and tried the lamb thali. both were very flavorful. still not a big fan of the chickpeas and lentils but there was this white yogurt thing that was pretty good. the mango chutney is delicious. the place is pretty lively and the ceiling is covered with puppets. they can be a bit scary if you look closely at them but they do add a very festive vibe. overall, it was a positive experience.

LsxDMLlNhYdtd9PNv_OnKw.text: im a huge fan of Masala Zones food. its consistantly good (although occationally they geta bit gung ho with the spices), doesnt make you sick and theres something for everyone. this particular location.... hit or miss.the decore and feel is pretty good. lots of things to look at. very comfortable. the first time i was in a rush. like in and out in 30 min rush. our charming waitress must have just point blank gone to the kitchen and demanded our food then and there because we even had time for dessert. love her.the second time, however.... sigh. i went for my birthday with a few friends, intent on taking my time and enjoying myself. everything went well till just after we finished our mains. one friend had to dash off early and wanted to pay for his part of the bill. the manager just didnt seem to understand.  ''We want to stay AND SPEND MORE MONEY, but can you just charge him for his portion?'' i finally had to do the ''you know what, just bring us the whole bill WE'LL GO SOMEWHERE ELSE.'' i kid you not.will i go again? of course. stupid manager be damned.

5twjZP6n4oC74IMbc3kkgQ.text: I like this restaurant for a myriad of reasons. The food is okay, the service is hit or miss, but the menu is varied enough that everyone can be happy.This past December, I loved it even more because it was the only restaurant that we could just walk into and get a table.  Mid December weekends in London can be hard to find a booking because many venues are full of Christmas Parties.

7enABe02Idk1iWVxcDLkWg.text: Masala Zone is part of a small chain of Indian restaurants.  I haven't been to any of the others in central London but this one is a favourite of mine.  It's an easy place to miss.  It's located almost on the corner of Bow Street and Floral Street, in the heart of Covent Garden, at the side of the Royal Opera House.  The food, service and décor are very good indeed.  I had a lamb thali on a recent visit, washed down with an apple & mint juice.  They were both delicious.  Despite its slightly out of the way location, the place was packed when I was there (which suggests that word of mouth recommendations, rather than a reliance on passing trade, are playing a big part in its evident success).  The efficient staff certainly go out of their way to make your visit as pleasant as possible.  My friend and I were bid goodnight and thanked for our custom when leaving (and that is a courtesy  that many restaurants of this ilk often overlook!).  Prices are very reasonable indeed (our two main courses and two drinks came to around £30).  And I must mention the delightful array of Rajasthani dolls that hang from the ceiling.  They add colour and spectacle to what is a very good budget dining experience.  Masala Zone, Covent Garden is definitely worth trying!

ecLemZbjUchAzQdzDmQ6Sw.text: As soon and my friends and I walked into this place we were impressed. The decor was something I have never seen before. There were these dolls hung on the ceiling and there is a open kitchen where everyone can see the different type of delicious food that is coming out of the kitchen. The service was excellent, and that is saying a lot for an American since we are use to the full service dining experience, with Europe not that focus on the service and all. Ok most importantly the food, it was delicious! When you order this combo kind of thing where you order 1 main curry and it comes with 3-4 different types of sauces to dip. It also comes with a little side of the chutney. It was such a dining experience being able to try 3-4 different kind of sauces. It was a very interesting dining experience and that is a place I will miss once I leave the country.

739kXNcoYf_5tZvyMNM7aQ.text: Hot on the heels of finding the Qype application for Android, I set about trying to find alternatives to the restaurants that I usually ended up at and this came highly recommended it seems. I don't know why. My friend and I arrived with anticipation of a good Indian meal and we left with the feeling of a mediocre Indian meal. The decor was interesting and functional, if not a little over-decorated (Especially with regards to the small legions of dolls on the ceiling!). The service was pleasant if not a little understaffed, and the price was definitely an agreeable one. The main problem however, was with the food. I admit that since moving down to London the bar has been raised as far as my expectations for restaurants is concerned, but I feel like the food simply doesn't measure up. The poppadums were room temperature and had a texture like they had been made a good long while ago (ie: Not crunchy). The main course, a Rogan Josh, came across as mediocre in flavour, with far too little meat and far too much sauce. In addition the meat was slightly dry and, again, of mediocre quality. The garlic Naan was nice, however it looked a lot more like a chapatti and tasted like it had been baked in an oven rather than cooked in a tandoor (Think a cross between tortilla and pitabread and you're on the right tracks). And it, like the main course, was inundated in coriander leaf. Coriander's nice, but it has a very soapy taste, especially when present in large quantities. On the other hand, the passion fruit sorbet was very nice and anywhere that does mango lassis can't be all bad in my books, but my experience with the poppadums and main course makes me think that this place likes to over-do it with pre-preparation and as a result loses the freshness, and with Indian cuisine (Or really ANY kind of cuisine) freshness is paramount to a good meal. Overall for the price I paid I don't mind the place, and it was a pleasant enough experience, but the food was mediocre at best. You may think I may be judging the place a bit too harshly, but the truth is I have had fantastic meals for a fiver more than this place (Which I believe is probably the reason why my bar is set so high!), and as a result I simply cannot recommend this place. Not when there's so much better for so little more out there.

sXavU0Mf6O4by7XFTM_SxQ.text: Great place for Indian.  I love their chicken kabob and tikka masala.

xjBwJaz24_w3aAtaCR2xEw.text: The service is outstanding, the food is very good, exquisite even, if you chose the right combination, and the price is relatively affordable (there are some promos as well), I've come here with friends, family, and the experience has always been excellent. As it is a really safe value I can't help recommending it even if I'm sure there are some better Indian restaurants in London, my ears are open, I'm ready to experience bliss...

8qMJ4nstO9ij-tIYLCUIqQ.text: Indian food for tourists. Limp naan, edgeless curries. Interesting presentation and nicely flavoured chaat.Abrasive ambiance and hurried (albeit friendly) service. Prices are high but competitive for neighborhood. Better than Brick Lane, but way sub-par for London Indian. Reserve for last-ditch post pub group dinners.

OnXs-rwOltUWzGeuOmDYIQ.text: I passed this place a few times when walking around Covent Garden, and thought it looked like a fab place to take my boyfriend for his birthday. WHAT A MISTAKE.We couldn't book a table so we joined the queue on a Friday evening - queues always make a place look good, so I was really hopeful and didn't mind waiting 10/15 minutes. The decor on the ground floor level is amazing - Indian puppets line the ceiling, filling the room with colour. To be honest that's ALL that impressed me through the entire evening.We finally made it to the front of the queue. Here's where it starts to go bad. We were offered a table around the corner, where no indian puppets hung, by the kitchen, and next to an electric fuse box that was letting off such an ear piercingly loud buzzing noise I didn't even sit down. I politely asked if we could have another table, and we were taken back to the front of the queue whilst they sorted out somewhere else for us to sit. To my amazement, they then tried to fob off the same buzzing table to the poor couple behind us! Lo & behold, that couple came back one minute later with the same complaint. Nice try.We were then taken downstairs (I didnt realise they even had a downstairs) to a large room with LOTS of empty tables, no decor at all compared to what was on the ground floor, and no ambience whatsoever - no music, no people, cold, bleak decor. Just awful.Again, I asked to have a table upstairs, as it had been the upstairs decor that lured us in. After another 10 minutes of waiting, we were finally seated at a table for two on the puppet floor. Thank God. We were STARVING at this point, having saved ourselves all day for this "incredible Indian food" we thought we'd be gorging on.We both ordered the platters of food, I think they're called Thalis. A big silver platter comes with tiny little bowls of food - basically like a trial & error testing dish. I hated all of it. My curry was meant to be mild & coconutty - it was bland, far too hot, and had no taste at all. My poor boyfriend, who's food was also disgusting, had lost his temper, anger got the better of him, and he decided he couldn't eat anymore. Poor guy, on his birthday too!To top it all off, the prices weren't great, so we forked out about £30 for a bland tasteless dinner of tiny weeny dishes, none of them that we liked.Honestly guys, don't go there. Try your local Indian instead - bound to be far better.And if you're in Covent Garden and need someplace good to eat, walk to Wardour Street and go to Busaba instead - my love affair with Thai food began in this very restaurant!!

tNC2p2L5Kp0qJiv-2lRApg.text: food was alright.  The best part of the restaurant is all the puppets hanging from the ceiling.

W_UOhQVuc_njTghjoJKVfg.text: Masala Zone is a growing UK chain, and attracting a lot of attention. They're just a step up from fast food; or perhaps the more accurate term would be street food, as you tend to get it in India. It's a bit like Imli (qype.co.uk/place/72917-I…) , though cheaper. Check out the menu (PDF) (masalazone.com/downloads…) . They have dozens of dishes,. Try the sev puri and clove-smoked lamb korma. Mmm. It's not luxurious or trying to be uber-authentic; it is honest about being an Anglicised Indian family restaurant, and honest about not being gourmet, but trying to aim for that reasonable middle ground. This location features north Indian specialities, and has hundreds of Rajasthani puppets hanging from the ceiling. Fun. There were also lots of Indian families eating here when I was last in, so take that hint. You can eat in the restaurant, obviously, or get takeaway or delivery (free over £15).

JK70aGjSDJJAPyc6HoN8BA.text: Masala Zone is great whether you're dining by yourself, as a couple or with a large group. I've eaten here numerous times sometimes sharing different plates, or ordering their great value Thali that holds a selection of small bite sized samples that definitely fill you up. I especially like the way that the Covent Garden location is decorated as they have all these hangings around the area that give it an interesting feel. It's the perfect place whether you want something fast, or just want to have a slow meal throughout the evening.

8k9k8axqGGUWZeDNI5cndg.text: This is a very smoothly run, moderately priced Indian restaurant in the heart of Covent Garden that shouldn't be missed by those who consider themselves well-versed in the cuisine of the sub-continent. We found both food and atmosphere conducive to casual conversation in a festive atmosphere. The Thali is delightful and nicely spiced.

EUaHUYtDnNtPOw8qRX09Dw.text: Masala Zone is the McDonald's equvilant of the Indian restaurant. Its alright if you want a quick feed, but are not too bothered about the quality, but you wouldn't go there to impress anyone. I've been there a couple of times and the food is ok at best. The first time the food was lukewarm and the second is was boiling hot, which smacks of food prepared much earlier and reheated as ordered. If you want a decent curry, I would recommend Sartaj on Earlham St, Seven Dials.

oFNTzrHwqynAYQlJPErCtQ.text: Ok, so the food was.decent, the restaurant was clean, and the staff pretty attentive but something lacked. I went on saturday night and the place was busy. On looking at the very limited menu, it is immediately obvious that this is not a traditional Indian restaurant that the majority of us are used to. It is as far from the Brick Lane type restarant as you could get! Best way to describe it is to imagine a fast turnover americanised version and you've probably got the picture.Food is very reasonably priced where a main course with rice for £9 is excellent BUT they are a rip-off for alcohol. I'm afraid any Indian restaurant that takes you for £3.50 for a tiny 300ml of cobra loses my vote (should be a pint for that price). Hope this helps you decide.

y0o0f953BzWlMhnMYa6Kcg.text: Situated just behind the Royal Opera House in a room thought to have been used by the company for storing costumes and where Pablo Picasso may have once painted a set used in a play, Masala Zone now makes and delivers a lot of real hot comforting Indian food to the residents of Covent Garden. At Masala Zone the cuisine is not limited to boring traditional dishes like Prawn,Lamb or Chicken cooked in a hurried takeaway style,but offers more interesting and healthier varieties that depict changing trends in Indian restaurant cookery. As more and more young British Asians tend to eat out their palates have become more discerning and eating habits in Great Britain tend to reflect that. The menu is split between street food and the well balanced Thali Meal. Either way the high quality of ingredients used in the preparation of the dishes is very indicative of the more affulent taste of Britain. After perusing the Masala Zone menu over a thick Mango Lassi and a juicy Mango Bellini we began with a vegetarian and warm meat grazing platters of street food.This came with a delicious Bhel-crunchy salad with crushed peanuts,Sev Puri,Chutney,Dhai Puri. For the carnivores in us there were the minced Lamb patties stuffed with herbs,steaming hot Chicken Samosas and minced Lamb Kebabs. The flavours were light,fresh and balanced by a cooling yoghurt which was made with tempering spice. Indian food does not have to be Chilli hot to be tasty.The Thali offers a choice of 12 curries all accompanied by Poppadums,Chutneys,Dhal,Rice and vegetarian dishes of the day. Not particularly adventurous with fiery cuisines I opted for the mildly spiced Prawn Malai flavoured with Coconut while my partner chose the spicer Lamb Rogan Josh. Both dishes were accompanied by a superb Pumpkin and Aubergine side dish, as well as a helping of perfectly cooked Basmati rice.

D996Y_YBdZNtKhkCElRMkQ.text: Dropped in here last year when I was at the Ideal Home Show and LOVED it! Had one of the thali's, don't remember which one, but was absolutely delicious, and a great value. Had plenty of vegetarian options for my picky mother as well. Definitely worth a try!

PgatEtUuEg0toGpnF1SnKg.text: This restaurant does not have a particulary nice view, but it is easy to find, well located and also nice decorated with lots of these indian dolls hangig from the ceiling. I have to admit that it has not a traditional indian design, but I like this modern touch about it.The restaurant offers all the usual indian dishes like beryani and daal, which taste very nice and over all it is reasonable priced.But i have to warn you with the dessert: some of these ones are just horrible. I ordred something that looked like and small whithe tennis ball unfortunatly it also tasted the same but hey no risk no fun.It is a good restaurant to go to, but I would recommend it more to the people that were already in every restaurant in Covent Garden and want to go for something different.

RxBxG5r0p2fos-1KuhHIyA.text: Excellent Indian restaurant in Covent Garden. We dined about 5pm so there were only another 4 tables in. The service from our main server was amazing. Very friendly and knowledgeable lady (think she was called Sharmila). She talked us all through the menu and different options and nothing seemed too much trouble. The food itself was very tasty and you got a lot of food for the money. We both had a grand thali and had trouble finishing them - and it was only £9!! Think our waitress went on break just as we'd finished our mains and service was definitely slower. However, would definitely eat there again!

Qcnkt8I-1sUgeK0YqWbb_g.text: i make a stop at Masala Zone every time i come to London. it's a favorite, for sure. The atmosphere is not-stuffy but not scary either. a good value especially when i am trading dollars for pounds.
